objects.name: CoolClient Evolution
objects.description: The Chinese espionage group is utilizing an updated version of its CoolClient backdoor. The new variant incorporates improved capabilities for stealing authentication data from browsers and monitoring the victim's clipboard content, indicating an effort to refine data exfiltration tactics.

objects.content:
Sector: Government, Technology, Private Sector (Espionage targets)

Modus operandi:
Deployment of updated CoolClient backdoor, utilization of multiple browser data stealers and scripts for persistent data harvesting.

objects.name: Widespread WinRAR CVE-2025-8088 Exploitation
objects.description: A wide range of actors, including state-sponsored groups (UNC4895, APT44, TEMP.Armageddon, Turla) and financially motivated groups, are actively and opportunistically exploiting the critical WinRAR flaw (CVE-2025-8088) to gain initial access and deploy various payloads, including RATs (AsyncRAT, XWorm) and infostealers.

objects.content:
Sector: Government (Ukraine), Military, Technology, Hospitality, Finance, General Public

Modus operandi:
Spearphishing leveraging geopolitical or commercial lures. Exploitation of path traversal via malicious RAR archives combined with Alternate Data Streams (ADS) to drop LNK or HTA files into the Windows Startup folder for persistence and subsequent execution of second-stage malware (e.g., NESTPACKER/Snipbot, POISONIVY, STOCKSTAY).

objects.name: CVE-2026-21509
objects.description:
Critical security feature bypass vulnerability actively exploited in the wild (Zero-Day). The flaw allows attackers to bypass Object Linking and Embedding (OLE) protections, enabling malicious code execution when a user opens a specially crafted Office document. Microsoft issued an emergency patch (Out-of-Band). CISA added it to the KEV catalog.

Affected product: Microsoft Office / Microsoft 365

objects.name: CVE-2026-24858
objects.description:
Critical authentication bypass vulnerability in FortiCloud Single Sign-On (SSO) feature. This zero-day vulnerability is confirmed as actively exploited in the wild. Fortinet mitigated the threat by blocking connections from vulnerable firmware versions while preparing a patch.

Affected product: Fortinet FortiCloud SSO

objects.name: CVE-2025-8088
objects.description:
High-severity path traversal vulnerability actively exploited by diverse threat actors (APTs and cybercriminals) since July 2025. The flaw allows attackers to craft malicious RAR archives that, when opened, drop files into arbitrary locations, commonly targeting the Windows Startup folder for persistence.

Affected product: RARLAB WinRAR

objects.name: CVE-2025-55182
objects.description:
Critical vulnerability (React2Shell) actively exploited to compromise systems worldwide. Exploitation leads to Remote Code Execution (RCE) and is used primarily to deploy crypto miners and botnets.

Affected product: React Server Components ('React2Shell')

objects.name: CVE-2026-23760
objects.description:
Critical authentication bypass flaw for which Shadowserver reported over 6,000 potentially vulnerable servers exposed online. CISA added this vulnerability to its KEV catalog.

Affected product: SmarterTools SmarterMail

objects.name: CVE-2026-1056
objects.description:
Critical arbitrary file deletion vulnerability in the Snow Monkey Forms plugin for WordPress (<= 12.0.3) due to insufficient file path validation. Exploitation is possible by unauthenticated attackers and can easily lead to Remote Code Execution (RCE) by deleting critical files (e.g., wp-config.php).

Affected product: Snow Monkey Forms Plugin (WordPress)

objects.name: Breach: SoundCloud
objects.description:
A significant data breach exposed personal details of approximately 29.8 million users (about 20% of its user base). The compromised data, resulting from unauthorized activity discovered in December 2025, included email addresses, names, usernames, and demographic information. The attackers reportedly attempted extortion before publicly releasing the data.

Sector: Media, Music Streaming

objects.name: Breach: Nike
objects.description:
Nike is investigating a potential cybersecurity incident after the WorldLeaks ransomware group claimed responsibility for stealing over 1.4 TB of corporate data. The threat actor announced the breach and threatened to release the stolen information publicly.

Sector: Retail, Sportswear

objects.name: Breach: Booz Allen Hamilton (US Treasury Contracts)
objects.description:
The U.S. Treasury Department canceled $21 million in federal contracts with Booz Allen Hamilton following a policy review related to a years-old insider leak (Charles Littlejohn) of confidential government data, highlighting the severe long-term financial and contractual consequences of internal breaches, even when the breach occurred previously.

Sector: Government Services, Consulting

objects.content:
Sector: Geopolitics, Defense, Technology

Theme: Strategic competition in the Arctic and the future of Greenland

The strategic importance of Greenland and the Arctic is increasing due to heightened geopolitical tensions between the US/NATO and the Sino-Russian axis. The US seeks to secure military control (anti-missile defense, GIUK gap surveillance) and future resource access (minerals, data centers) in the region. NATO, spurred by previous US pressure, is urged to significantly increase its defense commitment in the Arctic, making the region a critical domain for future global confrontation.

Tags: Arctic, NATO, Russia, China, Geostrategy

Sector: Technology, Finance, Sovereignty

Theme: Geopolitical and economic fragility of the global AI boom

An analysis suggests that the high valuation of major AI actors (e.g., NVIDIA, OpenAI) is based on fragile foundations, including lack of diversification, high energy demands, and dependency on critical supply chains (Taiwan). This AI growth diverts essential resources (talent, infrastructure) from other sectors, potentially leading to a broader economic recession outside the AI sphere. The analysis also highlights the competitive consolidation in quantum computing, illustrated by the potential Swiss acquisition of the French deeptech Quobly, underscoring the battle for technological sovereignty in critical domains.

Tags: AI, Quantum Computing, Economic Risk, Supply Chain, Sovereignty

The cyber threat landscape remains characterized by aggressive exploitation of critical vulnerabilities, highlighting the failure of organizations to apply patches promptly (N-day exploitation). Google Threat Intelligence confirmed that numerous threat actors—ranging from Russia- and China-nexus APT groups (UNC4895, Turla, APT44) to financially motivated cybercriminals—are widely exploiting the WinRAR path traversal flaw (CVE-2025-8088) for initial access. Furthermore, two new zero-days affecting widely deployed enterprise software were confirmed as actively exploited this week: a critical SSO authentication bypass in Fortinet FortiCloud (CVE-2026-24858) and a security feature bypass in Microsoft Office (CVE-2026-21509).

Technically, threats are evolving with new sophisticated TTPs, including the adoption of custom C2 communication methods that bypass standard API monitoring, and the emergence of campaigns specifically targeting Large Language Model (LLM) infrastructure endpoints. The commoditization of zero-day exploits by suppliers like "zeroplayer" continues to fuel both espionage and cybercrime operations. 

On the geopolitical front, strategic focus is centered on high-technology competition (Quantum computing and AI market stability) and the increasing militarization of the Arctic, specifically Greenland, driven by US/NATO strategy against the Sino-Russian axis.

objects.name: Advanced Malware C2 Evasion via Direct Kernel Interface (AFD/SSPI)
objects.description:
A new technique allows malware payloads to perform network communication (including HTTPS) by directly communicating with the Windows kernel's Ancillary Function Driver (AFD) using IO control codes, coupled with Microsoft Security Support Provider Interface (SSPI) for secure connections. This method bypasses standard high-level network APIs (WININET, WINHTTP, Winsocks) and their associated telemetry or security hooks, significantly complicating detection by endpoint security solutions.

Analysis:
This method represents a significant advancement in offensive tradecraft, moving away from easily monitored userland APIs into less-monitored kernel interfaces. Defenders must focus on detecting abnormal behavior, such as unauthorized IOCTL calls to AFD or unusual SSPI usage patterns, rather than relying solely on API hooking.

Recommendations:
- Implement strong monitoring for IOCTL calls directed at networking drivers (e.g., AFD) and analyze unusual sequences of system calls related to network establishment.
- Use deep packet inspection (DPI) to identify anomalies in HTTPS traffic originating from processes known to avoid standard Windows networking stacks.

objects.name: Bizarre Bazaar: Attack Campaign Targeting Exposed Large Language Model (LLM) Endpoints
objects.description:
A malicious campaign, dubbed 'Bizarre Bazaar', is actively targeting exposed LLM service endpoints. The objective is to commercialize unauthorized access to AI infrastructure, presumably for cryptocurrency mining, illicit resource consumption, or data theft, establishing a new vector against AI/ML systems.

Analysis:
The increasing focus on LLM endpoints reflects the value of underlying high-performance computing resources required for AI operations. This campaign signals the beginning of specialized exploitation targeting AI/ML cloud and enterprise infrastructure.

Recommendations:
- Review all LLM/AI service endpoint configurations to ensure they are not publicly exposed without strict access controls and zero-trust mechanisms.
- Monitor resource consumption (CPU/GPU cycles, network bandwidth) on AI infrastructure for unexplained spikes indicative of unauthorized use (e.g., crypto mining).

objects.name: New Phishing Trend: Email Thread Hijacking in Enterprise Environments
objects.description:
Attackers are bypassing standard email filters and user suspicion by inserting malicious messages directly into existing, legitimate enterprise email threads. This method, achieved typically through account takeover or supply chain compromise, leverages the inherent trust associated with internal or known partner communications to deliver phishing documents or malicious links, often targeting high-level discussions (e.g., executive document approvals).

Analysis:
This technique significantly increases the success rate of social engineering attacks, as the messages possess perfect contextual relevance and authenticity. It mandates a shift in security awareness training to focus on document verification and unusual requests within seemingly trusted communication flows.

Recommendations:
- Implement advanced detection capabilities that analyze email content and headers within existing threads for behavioral anomalies, not just known malicious links or attachments.
- Enhance user training to treat all unexpected file attachments or links, even within legitimate threads, with suspicion, emphasizing out-of-band verification for critical requests.

objects.name: CTI Report (EN) - 2026-01-28
objects.description: Aggregated CTI report for language EN
